scenario: I am a nurse with 12 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kiambu county in Kenya.   A 15-year-old male presented in our facility yesterday with a history of stool incontinence for two days. A patient has been having the incontinence two days prior.   The relative reports that the boy was sodomized by unknown people and then started having the stool incontinence and the pain. On examination, for sure there was the vitals were stable but the boy was in pain. The stool, there was real stool incontinence.   He could not hold the stool at all, at all. Should I start with post-care, post-labor care assessment? What will I do with the stool incontinence and should I involve even the police because it is a police case? Should I administer help and whom else could be of help to this patient?
clinician_response: SUMMARY A 5y/o boy with stool incontinence after being raped.  It is wise to think of reporting this particular case to the police. The boy will deserve to get justice. In the meantime, the child and the family should be counselled on the diagnosis and the course of its treatment.  i) Dietary advice - eat more fibre ii) Hygiene advice - reduce on prokinetics e.g: coffee, licorice iii) Use disposable absorbent undergarments iv) Time bowel movements v) Refer to a gastroenterologist for further management including a sphincteroplasty.

scenario: I am a nurse with 4 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kakamega county in Kenya.  I was just 20 years old. I brought a child for the first immunisation, that is at 6 weeks. The child was born at 3.3 kgs, but unfortunately when she was bringing the child for the immunisations, the child had dropped up to 2.2 kgs.  Now the mother looked stressed. Upon interrogation, she said that at home the mum is giving her stress, she is not giving her food, blaming her for the pregnancy and delivery because she was still at school. Now that situation confused me because I was wondering should I continue with the immunisations, should I refer the child for nutritional review or how will I help the mother.  Now that she has a new delivery case, no food is being provided by the mother, and I was just confused on what to do. Should I begin with the immunisations, should I refer for further management, should I refer for nutritional review, and how will I help the mother now that at her home the mother doesn't want to see her. When I shared it, I was wondering whether I should issue the immunisation first, or she should just seek nutritional review first and then come for immunisation later.  I wished I could get someone to give me those answers.
clinician_response: Summary 20 yr old mother concerned of dropping weight of the baby from 3.3 at birth to 2.2 kgs at 6 weeks She complains of stress and poor social support Key concerns i. Severe acute malnutrition ii. Poor social support Diagnosis Severe acute malnutrition, with potential differentials including: Congenital developmental abnormalities. Malabsorption syndromes.  Management Plan Immediate Interventions: Initiate fortified feeds to address malnutrition. Refer the baby to a facility with specialized pediatric care for further evaluation and management. Consultation: If a pediatrician is available, consult them for a detailed review of the baby’s condition. If no pediatrician is available, refer the baby to a facility with a child care unit. Counseling and Support for the Mother: Provide counseling to the mother to address her stress and guide her on proper infant feeding practices. Educate her on the importance of exclusive breastfeeding or using appropriate alternative feeds if breastfeeding is insufficient. Engage the Family: Call in family members to counsel them on the importance of providing emotional and social support to the mother. Long-Term Follow-Up: Monitor the baby’s weight, feeding habits, and overall growth. Ensure that both mother and baby receive ongoing psychological and nutritional support.

scenario: I am a nurse with 14 years of experience in General nursing working in a Dispensaries and Private Clinics in Kiambu county in Kenya.  I have a mother at first visit. She's 30 years old. She's part 4+0, gravida 5. After ANC Profile, the HB was 5.5. But everything else was okay. Weight also okay. Now, she has 34 weeks for gestation. Now, my question is, what should I give? So, yeah, the question is? What should I give? IFAS, Aferon or iron sucrose. And also, I wanted to know why the patient didn't come to ANC. What could be the reason?
clinician_response: Summary A 30 yr old Para 4+0 Gravida 5 presenting for her first antenatal clinc visit at 34 wks gestation Her haemoglobin is 5.5g/dl.  Problems * Severe anemia * Late antenatal clinic attendance  Management * Assess the probable cause of anemia * If it is Iron deficiency, give patient intravenous Iron infusion * Ensure patient continues with folic acid supplementation to prevent neural tube defects in the baby * Regular monitoring of blood pressure, haemoglobin, haematocrit * Consider blood transfusion if haemoglobin doesn't improve * Educate the patient on the need of eating iron rich food.  Investigations * Complete blood count- assess degree of anemia * Serum ferritin- to confirm iron deficiency anemia * Serum vitamin B12 & folate levels * Peripheral blood smear * Obstetric ultrasound to check for fetal well being & Amniotic fluid   Reasons for delayed antenatal attendance * financial constraints * lack of awareness * family issues * Distance from the health facility. Provisional diagnosis (Dx): Iron deficiency anemia

scenario: I am a nurse with 15 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kiambu county in Kenya.   A 28-year-old mother visited antenatal clinic with complaint of per-vaginal bleeding.  On history taking, she states that she had fallen while washing her house. On assessment, patient has active PV bleeding.   What investigation should I do? And how should I manage this patient till delivery of the baby?
clinician_response: SUMMARY 28 year old gravid female presenting with per vaginal bleeding secondary to trauma. Active bleeding noted on assessment.  Diagnosis - antepartum hemorrhage Management: Stabilization: Ensure hemodynamic stability with intravenous access (large bore IVs). Administer intravenous fluids (Crystalloids). Check hemoglobin levels; transfuse packed red cells or whole blood if needed. Obstetric Management: Obtain obstetric history. Perform abdominal exam to assess fundal height. Conduct a speculum exam to visualize the cervix. Perform an ultrasound to assess fetal health. Empiric Therapy: Administer empiric antibiotics. Manage pain with analgesics. Follow-Up: Ensure viability of pregnancy. Monitor vitals, bleeding, and educate patient to seek medical attention for worsening symptoms or recurrence of bleeding.

scenario: I am a nurse with 12 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kiambu county in Kenya.   A baby comes to the out patient department with the mother with complains of hottness of the body and convulsions ,each convulsion lasting 2 minutes with history of losing conciousness after every convulsion and hotness of the body which had lasted 2 days.On examination the baby was on A ,alert with a temperature of 38.5 but after assessment the baby convulsed again at the hospital.What is the immediate care for this child since the child is convulsing now,what can I give, is it diazepam but I cannot access the IV line ,can I give per rectal diazepam ,what is the cause of this convulsions ?Is it fever or this baby might need further investigations.
clinician_response: Summary  A baby brought with a history of hotness of body, convulsions, and loss of consciousness after the convulsion. On examination, the child is alert and has a fever (38.5°C). What is the immediate care? Ensure airway is patent and breathing is adequate. Give diazepam. If it recurs, give another dose of diazepam. If it recurs, give phenobarbitone. Check random blood sugars to rule out hypoglycemia. If present, give dextrose. Give antipyretic. Collect samples: Complete blood count - infections. Renal function test - electrolyte imbalance may cause convulsions. Blood smears to diagnose malaria. Lumbar puncture - Cerebrospinal fluid analysis to rule out/in meningitis. Do I give diazepam? Yes, it quickly stops the convulsion. Can I give rectal diazepam if I can't access an intravenous line? Yes, rectal diazepam is an option. If it feels or the baby might need further investigations: Complete blood count. Renal function test. Blood smears for malaria parasites. CSF analysis for meningitis. Head CT scan - rule out space-occupying lesions.

scenario: I am a nurse with 12 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kiambu county in Kenya.   A para 3 +2 gravida 6 mother visited ANC clinic for her follow-up care. She has a history of gestational diabetes. On assessment, her blood sugar level is 11 mmol per litre.   How do I manage the gestational diabetes during prenatal, intrapartum and postpartum period?
clinician_response: SUMMARY Para 3+2, gravida 6, history of gestational diabetes.Blood sugar: 11 mmol/L. Management of Gestational Diabetes Prenatal, Intrapartum, and Postpartum: Prenatal: Screening for gestational diabetes: OGTT (Oral Glucose Tolerance Test). Lifestyle change and modification: dieting and exercise. Support with medication: e.g., Metformin. Screening for preeclampsia, candidiasis, UTIs, and treatment. Monitor for complications like miscarriage, intrauterine fetal death. Obstetric scan to determine presence of fetal anomalies. Intrapartum: Close monitoring of sugars – random blood sugar. Anticipate for obstructed labor – fetal macrosomia. Monitor for increased risk of eclampsia – blood pressure. Lab work: full hemogram, renal function test. Anticipate for cesarean delivery – refer to higher-level facility and obstetrician. Have access to a pediatrician for close monitoring. Postpartum: Monitoring for sugar levels and control. Postnatal clinic follow-up. Medication – Metformin adherence. Monitor fetal well-being: i.e., higher risk of DIC, jaundice. Anticipate for fetal complications: i.e., hypoglycemia, jaundice; therefore, have access to a nursery and pediatrician. Psychoeducation on relapse in next pregnancy and chronic diabetes.

scenario: I am a nurse with 12 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kiambu county in Kenya.  44 year old mother, Para 0+0 gravida 1, came to maternity with complaint of lower abdominal pain, radiating to the back, increasing intensity and frequency. clinician_response: Summary 44-year-old mother who has delivered a stillbirth. The management of this mother should involve:  The management of the third stage of labor that includes: Administration of a uterotonic such as oxytocin to promote uterine contraction and control of bleeding. Uterine massage at the fundus to promote separation of the placenta and uterine contraction. Applying a controlled cord traction to remove the placenta. Monitor the patient for 1 hour after delivery for any early complications. Investigate the cause of stillbirth Provide counseling services regarding the loss of the fetus to ensure emotional support. Reassure the patient and respond to any fears or concerns that she might raise. Provide extension services

scenario: I am a nurse with 15 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kiambu county in Kenya. clinician_response: SUMMARY 1-year-old baby presenting with ingestion of Jik. Dx: Jik poisoning Management: Ensure the baby has a patent airway, normal breathing, and stable vitals. Do not induce vomiting to prevent further damage to the esophagus and oropharynx. Do not use milk and vinegar to avoid further damage. Place the child on the side to prevent aspiration. Consult a pediatrician for possible endoscopic evaluation. Give activated charcoal.  Give fluids.

scenario: I am a nurse with 12 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kiambu county in Kenya.  A multi-para, 42 year old, was brought to maternity after home delivery two hours ago with complaint of excessive per -vaginal bleeding. clinician_response: Summary A 42 year old multiparous was brought in after home delivery 2 hours with excessive per vaginal bleeding. On examination, there was extensive perineal tear, uterus was soft and mother had active bleeding. What is the management of Postpartum hemorrhage?  This is a case of Primary Postpartum hemorrhage, an obstetrical emergency. Management entails the following:  - Call for help from either a nurse or any other healthcare provider, a consultant is preferred. - Insert 2 large bore IV lines. - Collect blood samples for complete blood count and grouping and crossmatching and coag profile. - Inform the BTU (blood transfusion unit) for blood. - Insert a Foley urinary catheter to drain and empty the bladder. - Cover the patient, keep her warm to avoid hypothermia. - Put the patient in lithotomy position and do continuous bimanual compression of the uterus. - Give the following drug that will help to contract the uterus e.g oxytocin:  - - Insert an intrauterine Foley catheter and fill with 60 ml of NS to reduce uterine atony. - Assess haemodynamic status of the patient, in case she becomes haemodynamic unstable, transfuse whole blood. If bleeding persists inform the gynecologist for possible hysterectomy i or exploration  Diagnosis; postpartum hemorrhage

scenario: I am a nurse with 15 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kiambu county in Kenya. Keep the card dry and clean Apply topical antibiotics

scenario: I am a nurse with 12 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kiambu county in Kenya. clinician_response: A 16 year old female was brought in while unconscious. On assessment, blood pressure was 90/60, pulse rate 108 and pupils were pin point MANAGEMENT Conduct primary survey 1. Secure the airway- suction if needed. Use an airway adjunct e.g oropharyngeal airway Intubation required if patient is unable to maintain their airway 2. Breathing- assess respiratory rate, SPO2 and breath sounds Give oxygen is SPO2 is below 90% on room air 3. Circulation- check blood pressure, pulse rate, heart sounds- catheterize Insert intravenous line and take samples for full haemogram, urea creatinine and electrolytes, liver function tests, C-Reactive Proteins, Blood slide for malarial parasites, triple serology, blood gas analysis 4. Disability- Check for Glasgow coma scale, pupil size and random blood sugar. 5. Exposure- expose patients and check for any injuries Do a secondary survey o Take a sample history- ask about allergies, medications patient may have been on, past medical history, last meal and events around incident o Do a head to toe assessment Do a thorough systemic examination Order a CT head scan o If patient has taken organophosphate poison, give antidote Pralidoxime and give atropine If opioid overdose suspected give naloxone If head injury or CAN suspected do a head CT scan If malaria tests positive- give intravenous antimalarials o Counselling should be done only when definitive diagnosis obtained This should be done by the doctor and nurse in a quiet room. A psychological counsellor may provide support o The relatives should be given a chance to ask questions until satisfied

scenario: I am a nurse with 12 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kiambu county in Kenya.  A 35-year-old mother, para-0 +0 gravida-1, came for third ANC visit. Had complaint of headache, blurred vision, and on examination the mother had facial puffiness, epigastric pain, BP of 197 over 118, and history of one episode of convulsion. clinician_response: Summary  35 year old mother, Para 0+0 G1, 3rd ANC visit. Complains of headache, blurred vision. on examination: Facial puffiness, epigastric pain BP 197/118. History of one episode of convulsion. Diagnosis Eclampsia.  Differentials; Preeclampsia  MANAGEMENT OF ECLAMPSIA 1. Make sure the airways are clear and the patient can breathe. 2. Give antihypertensives e.g., Labetalol, methyldopa, nifedipine, hydralazine to control the pressure. 3. Put the patient on supplemental oxygen. 4. Insert IV large bore cannula. 5. Control the seizures: Give loading and maintenance dose of magnesium sulphate; monitor urine output and respiratory rate. 6. Give analgesics to soothe the headache and epigastric pain. 7. In case of respiratory arrest due to MgSO4, give assisted ventilation and calcium gluconate. 8. Keep patient Nil per oral on fluids. 9. Monitor vitals closely. 10. Call an obstetrician for further workup. 11. Monitor fetal heart rate (fetal heart rate).

scenario: I am a nurse with 15 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kiambu county in Kenya. clinician_response: Summary: A 2-year-old baby presenting with complaints of diarrhea, vomiting, fever, and refusal to feed for three days. The baby is dehydrated, lethargic, drowsy, and in shock. Management: Immediate management: The patient is in hypovolemic shock. Start with intravenous Ringer’s Lactate 20 mL/kg bolus over 15 minutes and reassess. If the baby is still in shock, administer a second bolus. Once the patient is out of shock, provide maintenance IV fluids (e.g., Ringer’s Lactate 70 mL/kg over 2.5 hours via NG tube). Other assessments: Check for hypoglycemia by assessing random blood sugar and managing accordingly. Assess pallor; if severe, perform transfusion. Reassess hourly and manage based on severity of dehydration (severe, some, or no dehydration). Additional interventions: Provide zinc supplements. Check for bloody stool, which would indicate bacterial gastroenteritis requiring antimicrobials eg metronidazole. Diagnosis: Gastroenteritis

Initiate patient on Iv fluids as Ps of obstructed labor ve you monitor The Power - do we have adequate contractions - augmented with oxytocin if inadequate uterine contraction. scenario: I am a nurse working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kiambu county in Kenya.  A patient who comes in with complaints of on and off infection, excessive urination, excessive intake of water, general body malaise, and the signs have been there for so long and fortunately or unfortunately she has not been attending our ANC clinic. She was attending somewhere where she was directed to do some of the tests, like urinalysis. It's a whole package of ANC profiles where it includes urinalysis and RBS and she had not done them.  And her assumptions were for the above signs, like for the urinalysis, for the frequent urination, it's because the baby is big, so the baby is pressing the bladder, so there is no space for the baby. So, I've said that those signs have been for so long, she couldn't trace the exact date. So, the assessment we did, all the investigations we did were urinalysis, a basic of urinalysis and blood pressure and an RBS.  And urinalysis just revealed glucose, glucose++++, that is four pluses, and an RBS which was basically high because it was around 34.5. And leukocytes, that is infection, she had a little bit of infection and the first thing you do, you inform the mother of the findings and how you're going to go about it so that you can do the management or you can handle the management in the ward. clinician_response: A 30-year-old female, 2 weeks postpartum, with fatigue and heavy PV bleeding. SVD birth with delayed placenta expulsion. PPH suspected, differential diagnosis with retained products of conception.  Perform Full hemogram: Check Hb for anemia of blood loss. Perform an ultrasound to check for retained products of conception as well as other possible reproductive pathologies.   Differential Diagnosis (DDx): PPH Retained products of conception Anemia of blood loss DIC  Management: Manage patient’s PPH with uterotonics (e.g., oxytocin). Give IV fluids for resuscitation (crystalloids). Give blood if Hb is severely low. Consider tranexamic acid (hemostatic agent). surgical evacuation through D&C or manual removal. Monitor vital signs. Lab tests to rule out coagulation disorders. Iron supplementation with iron sucrose.

clinician_response: A patient with palpitations, chest pain & loss of consciousness in church. A 24 yr old female with hx of prev. admission. 1st due to renal issues & HTN. On follow up. clinician_response: Summary: A 45-year-old female presents with complaints of severe epigastric pain radiating to her back, nausea, and repeated vomiting over the past 12 hours. scenario: I am a nurse with 14 years of experience in General nursing working in a Dispensaries and Private Clinics in Kiambu county in Kenya. clinician_response: SUMMARY 26 yr old gravid female presents with high blood pressure, generalized edema, urinalysis revealed protein in urine. A diagnosis of preeclampsia was made,symptoms worsened and patient started convulsing  Diagnosis - eclampsia  Why do you think the symptoms worsened? The worsening symptomatic presentation was because she did not receive magnesium sulphate Management Position the patient in left lateral position to prevent aspiration  secure airway and start oxygen if saturations are below 90 Start intravenous magnesium sulphate. Kindly refer to the nearest facility that has an obstetrician

scenario: I am a nurse with 14 years of experience in General nursing working in a Dispensaries and Private Clinics in Kiambu county in Kenya.  A man who presented to the facility with complaints of penile discharge, lower abdominal pains, and pain during micturation. We sent him for lab requests, where we did urinalysis. We sent for urinalysis VDRL and PITC, that is HIV testing.  The results came out and it showed that he was with VDRL positive, that is he had syphilis, and also HIV positive. We put him on medication and insisted that he should bring the partners for testing. Now the issue came in when we mentioned that statement and insisted that we should not disclose to his wife that he had syphilis and he was HIV positive.  Now the wife definitely came with the man's card the following day and I recognized the card. On interrogating the wife, the wife had no symptoms, she had no complaints, but we still sent her for the lab requests. The same lab requests, that is urinalysis with VDRL and HIV testing, but they all came out negative.  Fortunately the wife was negative in all the lab requests. Now the main question was, how? How was I going to tackle the case bearing in mind that the husband doesn't want his status to be disclosed to the wife? For one, I didn't want to bring down the marriage because a fight would arise. But then I was wondering, how were they going to live with this man without knowing his status?
clinician_response: Summary A man presenting with complaints of penile discharge, lower abdominal pains and pain during micturition. Labwork results came back showing VDRL positive for syphilis and HIV positive.put on medication and insisted to bring partner for testing. He refused that the partner have his results disclosed. Partner came and her results were negative.  Q1. How do I tackle the case? Consider ethical pillars - justice, autonomy, beneficence and non-maleficence Balance between patient autonomy and beneficence Respect patient confidentiality and autonomy to not disclose status to the wife In lieu of beneficence, counsel the husband on the importance of disclosing status to the wife Involve a psychologist or counsellor to encourage the husband to disclose. To educate and establish trust between the couple, initiate couple’s therapy For the sake of public health care, counsel the wife on the importance of safe sex practice i.e family planning, contraception, regular testing, use of post and pre exposure prophylaxis without disclosing to her her husband’s status. Write down everything, document the data.

scenario: I am a nurse with 15 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kiambu county in Kenya.  Still the same patient, the 52 year old male that had been admitted earlier with the diagnosis of persistent malaria, /typhoid and later developed hypertension which was not resolving despite the anti-hypertensives being administered. So on the 5th day the patient had several other tests that were run and among the tests was a discovery of sero-reactive that is HIV positive. So with this new development the patient was off balance and was unable to cope with the news of the new diagnosis and hence the patient became violent, the patient became rude, the patient became uncoperative and could not hold anything.   So the patient could verbalise even the name of the patient or the person who possibly infected him. And now this is the point where we got to know the reason for the persistent malaria, the recurrent malaria, persistent hypertension that was not going down. So it's at this point that we discovered that the patient also had anxiety which also led to the patient's state of mind to an extent that he ended up fighting even the staffs.  So at this point there was a query, are we dealing with a mental case that is a psychotic patient because the patient could not be handled, it was hard to manage and so the patient was referred to Mathare Hospital for the mentally challenged but on arrival they could not admit him there saying that this is not just a mental illness, we first deal with the medical issues before referring the patient back to Mathare and the patient was taken back to the hospital where even the fellow colleagues were fearing to handle him with having a history of being a security personnel, officer, that is the police. So a lot was at stake. Yes now we have come with a conclusive diagnosis, this client is newly diagnosed HIV positive.  So the question is, in such a situation what are you supposed to do? How do you break the news to the patient to ensure that this patient is going to cope and be able to continue with life because eventually we lost that patient, the patient died. So what killed this patient? Is it the hypertension, is it malaria, is it stress? What really killed the patient? What should we do in that situation? Number three, when you have a violent patient, one that you're supposed to administer medication despite the fact yes the patient may be stressed, maybe develops a level of malaria, complications of malaria, is an officer, a policeman whom you don't know whether you will just wake up with a pistol and shoot or whatever the case. Yeah, what is the best way to handle? Should you have security, more security around you as a personnel so that you are able to help this patient?
clinician_response: Summary: 52 year old Male admitted earlier with diagnosis typhoid peritonitis Later developed hypertension. Not resolving despite HTN drugs being given. On the 5th day, patient worsened. Had HTN; patient unable to cope with news and prognosis. Hence became violent; rude, uncooperative & couldn’t eat anything. He verbalized the name of persons who angered him:  Patient has anxiety too. He caught the staff. Referred to welfare but welfare refused and told him to handle the mental case first. Hospital stay was worsened since they heard he is a police guy. Q1: What should the health care provider do? Look for kin and Counsel together. Q2: Patient died - What could have killed the patient? Stress killed the patient together with untreated typhoid, adrenaline and hypertension. Q3:What should we do? Improve on counselling methods of parents. Early recognition of complications  Q4: Best way to handle a violent patient:  Use the existing protocols on handling agitated patient  Sedate. Diagnosis: CVA

scenario: I am a nurse with 15 years of experience in General nursing working in a Dispensaries and Private Clinics in Kiambu county in Kenya. As we know, diabetes is linked with immunosuppression and can lead to recurrent infections in the future  As for management, it is best to sit down and talk to the teenager, assess her psychological state regarding her situation as denial can be an obstacle to compliance with medication . clinician_response: A baby with rash (Still-birth).  1) What could have happened to the baby’s skin?  It is very common for newborns to develop rash on the skin even shortly after birth. Newborn acne is another cause of babies developing rashes.  Other dermatologic conditions, such as erythema toxicum, can cause rashes.  Allergic reactions could also cause rashes on the baby’s skin.

At 6.00 am, the mother had dilated 3 cm with mild contractions. At 11 am, she had dilated 4 cm with mild contractions which are progressing quickly. At 4 pm, there were very strong contractions but the mother was uncooperative. The baby was noted to be in fetal distress and a cannula was unable to be fixed. The baby was delivered with an APGAR score of 4.5.5.  Diagnosis: Severe birth asphyxia.  Was there a missing gap? How would you tell when a client has precipitated labour?  Management of labour Administer analgesics for pain relief IV access at an early stage Give IV fluids such as normal saline and dextrose 10% Early ambulation to help in contractions Obstetric ultrasound to elicit the weight of the baby which will lead to an early intervention In case the baby is big, prepare of emergency cesarean section Do Full hemograms, Urea Electrolyte Creatinine and urinalysis  The client with precipitated labour- it comes very fast without you knowing and the healthcare giver should be ready at all times for such circumstances

scenario: I am a nurse working in a Health centres in Kiambu county in Kenya.  A student visits outpatient with history of cramps, low abdominal pains which are crampy in nature, backache, headache and dysuria. Question 1. Which medication do I administer? Question 2. Which lab test do I send for?
clinician_response: Summary Student with a history of cramps, lower abdominal pains (crampy in nature), backache, headache, dysuria.  Q1. Which medications should I administer? This is concerning for a UTI. If the patient tests positive for a UTI, treat with Nitrofurantoin or third generation cephalosporins or Septrin if the patient’s pregnancy test is negative. If the pregnancy test is positive, treat the UTI with Nitrofurantoin in the first or second trimesters. If in the third trimester, treat with cephalosporins or Amoxiclav and advise the patient to visit the antenatal clinic.  Treat the pain with analgesics to relieve the backache and headache. To manage the abdominal cramps, treat with a muscle relaxant.  Q2. Which lab tests? Test for pregnancy - Urine pregnancy test Do a urinalysis - dipstick, microscopy, culture and sensitivity to confirm urinary tract infection and the causative organisms if present. Test for STIs if any sores or per vaginal discharge are present. Do a full hemogram for baseline tests. Radiological investigations - abdominopelvic ultrasound if pregnancy tests are positive to check on the fetus

clinician_response: summary: A pregnant woman presents to the antenatal clinic with a 3 day history of reduced fetal movements. Problems Reduced fetal movements No fetal heart sounds Financial problems  Management Refer to a referral hospital with obstetric and gynaecologist services, involve social worker to arrange for transportation and discuss financial assistance for ultrasound  Provide emotional support Check vital signs regularly If an intrauterine fetal demise is confirmed via ultrasound induce Labor prepare for Cesarean section if there is obstructed labor Monitor maternal health after delivery.  Investigations  Obstetric ultrasound to confirm cardiac activity Do a Doppler ultrasound if available to assess blood flow of fetus Perform a Complete blood count for anaemia Do a Coagulation profile to check for disseminated intravascular coagulation Do a Blood grouping & cross match to prepare for transfusion Do a urinalysis to rule out infection Do Thyroid function tests to rule out hypothyroidism  Diagnosis:  Intrauterine fetal demise

scenario: I am a nurse working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kiambu county in Kenya.  A mother comes in with a child 3 years old. On examination, the child has stunted growth, very emaciated and lacks energy. What are the available counselling options on nutrition for this child.  What is the most appropriate and available supplementary foods? Establish whether the client is in a position to afford three balanced meals per day and how to explore possible referral options.
clinician_response: Summary:  A 3-year-old child presents with stunted growth, very emaciated and lacks energy.  Differential diagnosis: protein-energy malnutrition  The first step would be to do a social background check to find out the reason behind the child’s current state.   Before introducing supplementary foods, attempt to treat the acute setting by employing the 10 steps of treating severe acute malnutrition preferably as per the basic pediatric protocol. The 10 steps can be summarised as treatment of hypoglycaemia, ready to use therapeutic foods/ vitamins supplementations, maintaining adequate temperature, encouraging stimulating environment and a good support system.  NB: Avoid feeding the child normally to prevent refeeding syndrome and treat Severe Acute Malnutrition instead  In terms of counselling options, encourage incorporation of high-protein diet and this should be mirrored to the available local sources.  Encourage small frequent meals and a balanced diet.  In terms of available supplementary foods, we encourage foods that are rich in multivitamins and folic acid supplementation easily available and affordable to the client.

scenario: I am a nurse working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kiambu county in Kenya. clinician_response: Summary: A patient on Depo Provera reports lower back pain, intermittent bleeding and pruritic vulva. Vitals within normal range.  DIAGNOSIS - Vaginal candidiasis  a) Could it be the client is not favored by this FP method.  * Depo Provera can cause adverse effects such as bloating, nausea etc.  * Hormonal birth control methods can however alter the pH of the vagina, which could lead to bacterial overgrowth or yeast leading to conditions such as Bacterial Vaginosis. This can cause itching and irritation. b) Is it possible to explore other causes of family planning?  * Non-hormonal methods of contraception such as Copper IUD can be used.

scenario: I am a nurse working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kiambu county in Kenya.  20-year-old woman comes to the facility and has been on Depo-Provera as a family planning method, had complaints of intermittent PV bleeding for the last six months. How do I manage the hormonal imbalance? Should I counsel for an alternative method?
clinician_response: A 20-year-old woman on Depo-Provera, with intermittent PV bleeding for 6 months.  (a) Management of hormonal imbalance:  Progesterone therapy for endometrial stabilization and reduction of irregular bleeding if Depo-Provera is the proven cause of imbalance.  Manage any other cause of hormonal imbalance, i.e., thyroid disorders or other endocrine disorders, accordingly. Give methimazole or propylthiouracil for any hyperthyroidism.  Treat any pelvic infections that would be the cause of bleeding.  Manage any endometrial pathology, i.e., fibroids, malignancy, polyps, adenomyosis, etc.   (b) Yes, counsel on Depo-Provera alternatives, i.e.:  Barrier methods, i.e., condoms.  Copper intrauterine device → Non-hormonal methods.  Combined oral contraceptives → Regular bleeding is restored, with a predictable menstrual cycle.

On examination, the temperature is 38.8 and a foul smelling discharge is evident. What is the most appropriate treatment for this case? What are the best counseling options ?
clinician_response: 45 year old female with pruritic vulvae, lower abdominal pain, and foul smelling vaginal discharge Temperature of 38.8%.  Differential Diagnosis Vulvovaginitis Pelvic inflammatory disease Abscess  Appropriate treatment;  Swabs should be taken from the vaginal canal to be taken for microscopy, culture and sensitivity. The choice of antibiotics should be based on the results from the lab. A combination of oral medication and pessaries can be given. Full haemogram should be done. A confirmatory ultrasound scan to rule out pelvic inflammatory disease or presence of a deep abscess. Analgesics should be given for the pain, and a topical antihistamine can be given to relieve the pruritus.  Counselling; A counselor should be involved in this process. It would be wise not to judge the patient but rather to inform and educate her. Matters such as the number of sexual partners, safe sex practices using protection should be considered and discussed.

What could be the possible heart defect that the infant is experiencing?where should I refer the baby?,does the condition require medical treatment or surgery? what if it's a heart defect that cannot be repaired? what is the fate of the baby?
clinician_response: SUMMARY 3 weeks old neonate brought to Sub county hospital Complaints: Blue discoloration of extremities, easy fatigability on feeding, FTT. On Examination: Vitals NORMAL 3rd heart sounds auscultated. Q1: POSSIBLE HEART DEFECT. Cyanotic heart diseases e.g., Tetralogy of Fallot Transposition of great vessels. Truncus arteriosus. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Return. Hypoplastic Left Heart Syndrome. Q2: WHERE TO REFER BABY? To a facility with Echocardiogram for diagnosis. Paediatric cardiologist for management - Both supportive and definitive care. Inpatient care. Q3: TREATMENT. Initially may require medical treatment depending on findings on Echo. Further management with no determination after diagnosis is confirmed and cardiologist consulted depending on the lesion. Q4: If it's a heart defect that can't be repaired, they will benefit from supportive management and palliative care. Q5: Fate of baby is dependent on definitive diagnosis and findings on Echo. Diagnosis: Cyanotic heart diseases e.g. DDx:Tetralogy of Fallot Transposition of great vessels. Truncus arteriosus. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Return. Hypoplastic Left Heart Syndrome.

scenario: I am a nurse with 12 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kiambu county in Kenya.  A 13-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department with complaint of surgical site bleeding. The father reports that the boy had underwent a circumcision procedure two hours ago done by a clinician in a clinic near their home. On examination, there is active bleeding and a blood vessel that had not been adequately clamped during the procedure was identified.  What is the immediate management of this patient?
clinician_response: SUMMARY A 13-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department at a sub county hospital with complaints of surgical site bleeding. Reports that circumcision had been done 2 days ago. On examination, there was active bleeding at the site of the wound, and a blood vessel had not been clamped. Differentials: Coagulopathy. Thrombocytopenia. Hemorrhagic shock. Immediate Management: Stop bleeding; admit to minor theatre. Take informed consent. Do labs, e.g., Complete blood count, Urea, electrolytes and creatinine, Liver function tests. Give IV fluids such as Ringer's Lactate. Give antifibrinolytic to stop bleeding. Catheterize the patient and monitor input and output. Consult a urologist to review the patient. Investigations Full hemogram-platelets Coagulation profile Blood grouping and cross matching Blood culture

scenario: I am a nurse working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kiambu county in Kenya.  A baby aged 2 days post delivery is brought to the OPD with complaints of yellow eyes and yellow skin. She was born at term via caesarean section with bwt of 3500gmswith no complications,on examination, the skin looked dry,, dehydrated+, bilirubin levels done and were 282,high temp of 36, other obs within normals   Should I refer for phototherapy or exchange blood transfusion? What could be the cause of the neonatal jaundice? What are the long term effects of jaundice in neonates?
clinician_response: Summary 2 day old baby post delivery with yellowness of eyes and skin. Was born at term via cesarean section with birth weight of 3500g.No complications occurred. On the physical exam, dry skin, dehydrated. Bilirubin levels were 282. High temperature of 36. Other vitals were normal. Q1. Should you refer for phototherapy or exchange transfusion? Yes you should refer for phototherapy,  Threshold is 240 mmol/L of total bilirubin.  283 is above the threshold plus the child is clinically jaundiced.   Q2. Causes of neonatal jaundice Hemolytic disease of newborn Metabolic disorders like hypothyroidism Pyloric stenosis leading to increased enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin Polycythemia  Q3. Long term effects of neonatal jaundice Main one is kernicterus-brain damage due to high levels of bilirubin. Have seizures, hearing loss, learning difficulties and involuntary movements Bilirubin induced neurological dysfunction-neurotoxicity to brain Neurodevelopmental disorders -developmental delays and infantile cerebral palsy.  DX:  Neonatal jaundice

scenario: I am a nurse working in a Health centres in Kiambu county in Kenya.  A 7 yr old boy brought to hospital with history of fall from a tree and sustained a deep cut on the right side of the face extending to the eye.On examination,the right eye had a deep cut and was oozing blood and tears.He was also noted to have fracture of the left hand. clinician_response: SUMMARY  A 7-year-old boy was brought to a health center in Kiambu county health center after falling from a tree and sustaining a deep cut on the right side of the left hand. He sustained an injury to his right eye as well. On examination, the right eye had a deep cut and was oozing blood and tears.  How do I manage the cut eye? 1. Stop the bleeding from the eye by applying direct pressure using an eye pad. 2. Apply atropine eye drops to the eye. 3. Bandage the eye. 4. Place the head in an elevated position. 5. Give prophylactic antibiotics and analgesics for the pain. 6. Refer to be seen by an ophthalmologist.  How do I refer the patient? Ensure to address the life-threatening conditions first. Refer to a higher-level hospital. Before referral, splint the hand to minimize pain and give analgesics that are available.

scenario: I am a nurse working in a Health centres in Kiambu county in Kenya.  A 17 year old was brought to the facility at night, hysterical and screaming. Well until 10 pm when she screamed saying she had a headache. Did not respond to first aid given. Differentials: Hysteria. Psychosis. Delirium. Management: Calm the patient – diazepam stat dose. scenario: I am a nurse working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kakamega county in Kenya. clinician_response: SUMMARY  7 day old neonate brought in with complaints of refusal to breast and convulsions. . on examination temperature was at 38.6, and has dehydration (Skin pinch greater the 3 sec.) CBC shows elevated WBC  Dx Febrile convulsions Dehydration Septicemia Malaria  Does the baby need admission for further management? Yes, requires urgent intervention:  1. scenario: I am a nurse working in a Health centres in Kakamega county in Kenya.  An HIV positive mother, who had just delivered, abandoned her newborn baby in a postnatal ward and disappeared. clinician_response: Summary HIV-positive mother delivered and abandoned her newborn and disappeared. She is married to an HIV-positive husband. The mother has not been on HIV prophylaxis.  Management Start the neonate on appropriate anti-retroviral drugs: Nevirapine and Zidovudine at least 6 hours post delivery. Refer to antiretroviral therapy clinic.

scenario: I am a nurse working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A 10 year old boy is brought in having drowned in a water pond. On examination, the body clothes are wet and has a full stomach. So, the question I ask myself is, which best position can I put this client on? clinician_response: SUMMARY A 10-year-old boy is admitted after falling into a pond. He has a full stomach. Best positioning? How to extract the water?  Differential Diagnosis Drowning  Possible aspiration.  Steps: Put the patient in a recovery position to limit aspiration. 1. Kneel beside the patient. 2. Extend the arm closest to you. 3. Bend the other arm at a right angle. 4. Bend top leg. 5. Straighten the other leg.  Caution: Do not attempt removal of the water. Consult your physician for proper comprehensive care.

scenario: I am a nurse with 7 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kakamega county in Kenya. scenario: I am a nurse working in a Health centres in Kakamega county in Kenya.  So i received a client in the out patient a male 17 years old, he had a history autism this time he presented with rectal prolapse and fever and suicidal thoughts. Since he is autistic, he lives his grandmother who is unable to take care of him properly, she doesnt even understand what the needs of this boy are, its through assesment that i realised that this boy had suicidal thoughts and i was asking myself are there any services in the community or maybe in the county level that can cater for this kind of patients so that we avoid the suicides that come out of this kind of clients, what can i do for this patient? clinician_response: Summary A 17 year old male with history of autism presents with rectal prolapse, fever and suicidal thoughts. Lives with grandmother who struggles to meet his needs. Problems - Rectal prolapse - Fever - Suicidal thoughts - Inadequate caregiving - Autism Management - Reduce the prolapse manually if feasible by use of gentle pressure with a glove. - If irreducible refer urgently for surgical intervention. - Administer antipyretics for fever. - Provide a calm non-judgemental environment. - Engage a psychologist for adjustment and intervention. - Refer to a tertiary care facility and a surgeon for further intervention. - Involve a social worker to aid in financial problems. - Advice on dietary adjustment and fiber intake to prevent rectal prolapse. Investigation - Complete blood count to access anemia - Stool examination for ovarian cyst - Mental health assessment

scenario: I am a nurse with 21 years of experience in General nursing working in a Health centres in Kakamega county in Kenya. Imaging by a plain CT scan, CXR, and X-ray for all limbs, face, and head.  Any other findings from clinical observation should be reported for prompt management.  Let me know if further clarifications are needed!   Diagnosis: POLYTRAUMA .

scenario: I am a nurse with 7 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A 10 days, new birth was delivered through caesarean section. The baby's score was 7 in 1 minute, 8 in 5 minutes, and 10 in 10 minutes. She developed birth asphyxia. SPO2 at 78% onRA,on o2 0.5 hrs/min,temp.34.9,RR 48b/mm.PR 118 b/mm premeds-antibiotics,oxygen therapy semiconscious on N6 feeds  DIAGNOSIS: -Hypoxic Ischaemic Encephalopathy due to Birth asphyxia. Diagnosis: -Hypoxic Ischaemic Encephalopathy due to Birth asphyxia.

scenario: I am a nurse with 7 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kakamega county in Kenya. scenario: I am a nurse working in a Health centres in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A female born aged 32 years comes to the clinic for a drug briefing and contests that the spouse prohibits her from leaving the home to refill her drugs. He denies her food and sometimes pulls her out of the house at night. The mother has children from a previous marriage that are not going to school though they are of school-going age.  The mother is requesting the health care provider to assist her in the abusive marriage. Is it proper for the health care worker to assist the client in the abusive marriage by reporting to the various social and child support services?
clinician_response: SUMMARY A 32 year old reports being in abusive marriage.  MANAGEMENT OF THE PATIENT.  As a healthcare provider you are required to assist the client by reporting to the appropriate social and child support services.  Healthcare workers have the duty of protecting individuals who are vulnerable. They are also advocates of patient safety.  Therefore the steps you should take as a nurse is to engage the patient and ensure confidentiality, assess any immediate dangers, connect the client to gender based violence support services.
