Her husband always assaults her every time.  She has nowhere to go and she has nothing to do. She asks me to advise her what to do, what can I tell the client.
clinician_response: Summary  A 30 years old woman presents with a history of being assaulted by her husband. Dx: Gender-based violence  Management: Involvement of gender-based violence advocates. Psychological counseling.

scenario: I am a nurse working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A young child is brought to the facility with complaints of swallowing a one shilling coin and it's stuck on the throat 30 minutes ago. On examination, the child looks irritable and has a laboured breathing. And on further examination, there is some cyanosis elicited in the extremities.  One, what emergency procedure can be done to relieve the airway? And two, what are the other interventions that will be done to the child to manage the situation?
clinician_response: SUMMARY: Young child History: Swallowed a coin stuck in the throat 30 minutes ago. Presentation: Irritability, labored breathing, cyanosis on extremities. Emergency Procedure to Relieve Airway: Urgent bronchoscopy under general anesthesia. Other Interventions to Manage Situation: 1. Administration of supplemental oxygen via high-flow nasal cannula to relieve work of breathing while awaiting intervention. 2. Chest X-ray to confirm diagnosis and locate the foreign body. Diagnosis: Foreign body in the airway (aspiration).

scenario: I am a nurse working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A neonate of six days is brought to the facility with complaints of hotness of the body, unable to breastfeed and irritability for two days. In examination, the umbilical cord drains fast and has foul smelling. The mother claims she has been applying chlorhexidine cord care as guided by the nurse upon delivery.  A diagnosis of neonatal sepsis is made. 1. Should I place an NGT for feeding or engage the nutritionist for nutritional interventions? 2. What is the best regimen of antibiotics for such a client?
clinician_response: Summary Neonate 6 days old brought in with complaints of hotness of body, inability to breastfeed and irritability for 2 days. O/E umbilical cord drains fast and foul smelling fluid. Diagnosis of neonatal sepsis made.  Differentials: Pneumonia Meningitis Respiratory distress syndrome  Should I place an NGT for feeding or engage a nutritionist for intervention? Yes, place and NGT for feeding Advise mother to express milk onto a clean cup and feed the child using a syringe. Teach the mother on clean practices when feeding the baby. Ultimately, breast milk is the best form of nutrition for the baby Nutritionist to intervene if the mother is not producing enough milk, to give the mother dietary counselling and provide the baby with supplemental feeds What is the best regimen of antibiotics for such a patient? First line: Gentamicin and Penicillin or Ampicillin Second line Ampicillin and Gentamicin Third line Amikacin and piperacillin - tazobactam

scenario: I am a nurse with 26 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A three-year-old baby came to outpatient department accompanied by the mother with history of having ingested poison. On examination the child was unconscious but not smelling poison and not responding to stimuli. Observations that were taken temperature was 36.2 degrees centigrade pulse was 134, respiration was 30.   Might this be poison or is it another condition? Which test should I do? Should I give this child IV fluids to resuscitate her? Should I do gastric lavage or should I just refer this patient to a pediatrician for further management?
clinician_response: 3 years old baby with history of long prison ingestion child is unconscious and unresponsive Vitals-36.2 Pulse rate-143 Respiratory rate-30  Diagnosis (Dx); Ingestion of unknown poison DDx: organophosphate poisoning  Immediate management –Remove any clothing Follow the ABCDE approach Obtain oxygen saturations of <95% start oxygen  Get intravenous access and get samples for the labs  Start intravenous fluids perform any random blood sugar  Collect any evidence of the poison -Ensure that the child is stable before referral -Position the child laterally to prevent aspiration  Gastric lavage is recommended when the ingestion of poison occurrences within 2 hours and if the chemical on the poison ingested is known In the referral facility the following investigations will be done ; Toxicology screen to identify the toxin through blood and urine tests  Urea/Electrolyte/Creatinine

scenario: I am a nurse with 26 years of experience in General nursing working in a County Hospitals in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A two-year-old baby was brought to outpatient department with history of having swallowed a coin. On examination, the patient had difficulty in breathing, not able to swallow saliva. Observations were taken and temperature was 36 degrees centigrade, pulse was 1.3 per minute and respiration was 28 per minute.  An impression of respiratory blockage was made. What should I do to this child? If I give oxygen, will she benefit or should I just refer this patient to the next level for further management?
clinician_response: Summary  2-year-old baby presents with a history of swallowing a coin. On examination, difficulty in breathing, inability to swallow saliva. Vitals are normal.  Impression of respiratory blockade was made.  IMMEDIATE MANAGEMENT 1. Do an X-ray to confirm the position of the coin. 2. Suction any drooling. 3. Put on nasal prongs supplemental oxygen. 4. Call physician and surgeon for emergency review. 5. Try abdominal thrusts to dislodge the coin upwards. 6. May require bronchoscopy for removal. 7. Give analgesics for the pain. 8. Give prophylactic antibiotics (broad spectrum).

scenario: I am a nurse with 26 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A one-year-old baby boy was brought to outpatient department with burns on the body, on the chest and tummy. On examination the burns were superficial on the chest and the whole tummy. Observations were taken, temperature was 37.5 degrees centigrade, pulse was 134 per minute, respiration was 28 per minute, a diagnosis of superficial burns was made.   Should I admit this patient in the ward or should I give fluids first and dress the wounds before I take the patient to the ward? Which treatment can I start the patient on?
clinician_response: Summary: 1-year-old with burns on the chest and abdomen. Low grade fever 37.5, PR-134 Diagnosis: Superficial burns with sepsis DDx: Trauma  Pneumonia  Management: Pain management with analgesics. Clean and dress the wounds with appropriate topical agents. Monitor fluid intake and administer tetanus toxoid if needed.

scenario: I am a nurse with 26 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A three-year-old baby was brought to outpatient department accompanied by her parent with history of having put a foreign body in the nose. On examination a bean seed was seen in the left nose. Observations were taken, temperature was 38 degrees centigrade, pulse was 128 per minute, respiration was 28 per minute.   A diagnosis of foreign body was made. What should I do? Do I try to remove this seed from the nose or I'll be worsening the situation? Or should I just refer this patient to the ENT specialist? Which treatment should I put this baby before I refer her?
clinician_response: SUMMARY A 3 year old baby has a history of putting a foreign body in the nose. On examination there is a bean seed in the left nostril. He is febrile - 38°C. This patient has a foreign body in the nose. Due to the risk of aspiration, do not attempt to remove the bean. This patient is febrile, therefore, they can be given antipyretics e.g. Paracetamol Per rectally. This patient is then referred to an ENT Specialist for removal of the foreign body.

scenario: I am a nurse with 26 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A five-year-old child was brought to outpatient department with history of having taken a known drug. On examination, the child was smelling some funny, there was funny smell from the child's mouth and the patient was in semi-conscious state. Observations were taken.  Temperature was 36 degrees centigrade. Pulse was 108 per minute. Respiration was 22 per minute.  A diagnosis of drug intoxication was made. Should I do gastric lavage to this patient? Which drugs should I give to counteract that poison? Should I start this patient on fluids or should I admit this patient to the ward for further management and observation?
clinician_response: Summary: A 5 year-old child brought with a history of ingesting an unknown drug. On examination, there is a foul smell from the mouth. Child is semi-conscious.  Vitals are normal  Management Stabilize the child using ABCDE approach Try to establish the medication that the child could have ingested and whether they have any chronic medication for known morbidities Give supplemental 02 via a non-rebreather mask, target 95% saturation Organise for urgent referral to a facility with HDU/ICU care as the patient might require ventilation support if she remains semi-conscious before the identity of the drug is established for an antidote to be given. Will require labworks: Complete Blood Count, urea electrolyte and creatnine s, liver function tests, coagulation profile to check for alarming changes Will need effective input/output management Needs admission under care of pediatrician Avoid gastric lavage as that can cause aspiration which will worsen the child’s condition

scenario: I am a nurse working in a Dispensaries and Private Clinics in Kakamega county in Kenya.  During a family planning, a counseling session in the family planning clinic, a 35-year-old agrees to do cervical cancer screening. There is no history of pain, vaginal bleeding or previous positive results. On assessment, the VIA turns positive.   Her cervix is easily, her cervix easily bleeds or touches. What medications can I give? Do I withhold family planning? Where can I refer for further management?
clinician_response: 35 year old agrees to cervical cancer screening. No history of pain, vaginal bleeding,or previous positive tests. on examination visual inspection with acetic acid turns positive. Cervix easily bleeds on touch. DDx: The above symptoms are highly suspicious for Cervical Intraepithelial Neoplasms (CIN) caused mostly by HPV. Differentials of: Leukoplakia, vaginal warts. MANAGEMENT + Referral??: Refer patient to gynecologist for further workup. In case of heavy bleeding onset, give tranexamic acid. Do coagulation profile to r/o coagulopathies. Ask for visual inspection with acetic acid Human Papilloma Vaccination history . Sexual education and advice on ways of preventing Cancer of the cervix and the risk factors.

scenario: I am a nurse working in a Dispensaries and Private Clinics in Kakamega county in Kenya.  As a 16 year old is brought to the outpatient with complaints of refusal to feed and excessive fasting, she has also a history of being choosy with food. This started one year ago after joining high school. She was bullied due to her being overweight.   On assessment, she's dehydrated and has a BMI of 18.5. Could this be anorexia nervosa or bulimia nervosa? How should I help this client and her parents?
clinician_response: Case summary A 16 year old presented with refusal to feed and excessive fasting. She has a history of being choosy with food. She was bullied secondary to being overweight. On examination, she was dehydrated. BMI of 18.5  Key concerns Refusal to feed History of being bullied secondary to being overweight  This is a concern for anorexia nervosa  Management Fluid therapy to ensure adequate fluid intake parenterally Give multivitamins Family therapy for support Individual therapy to get past the bullying and also be advised on the importance of a healthy diet Nutritional review

scenario: I am a nurse working in a Dispensaries and Private Clinics in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A 17 year old is brought to the outpatient department by a neighbor. He has complaints of painful edification and inability to sit down for the first three days. He moved to live with the uncle a week ago.   They live alone in the house with the uncle. He has no previous complains. On examination, the anus looks bruised and bloodstained.  There is no swelling noted. The boy looks scared and has refused to talk. Could this be a case of sodomy? Could this be hemorrhage? How best can I help the boy?
clinician_response: A 17 year old boy who recently moved in with his uncle comes with the complaints of painful defecation and inability to sit down for three days. On examination, the patient was scared and refused to talk and the anus looked bruised and bloodstained but with no swelling.  The differential diagnosis are as follows; Sodomy Anal fissure Anal hemorrhage  The patient should be managed as follows; Start the patient on analgesics Have a psychological counsellor involved in order to get the history of the case Take blood samples for the following lab tests- Complete blood count, Liver Function Tests, Triple serology Call the uncle to the hospital to get a further history Involve a social worker on the case Admit the boy if safety is a concern.

scenario: I am a nurse with 26 years of experience in General nursing working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A male child was brought to outpatient department. She was 8 months old. On history taking, the mother said she had convulsed for one day.  On examination, the patient had fever and was still convulsing. Observations were taken. Temperature was 39.5 degrees centigrade.  Pulse was 134. Respiration was 36 beats per minute. Might this be malaria? Which test do I do? Should I send this child for BS to the lab? Or should I give an anticonvulsant first? Should I admit to the ward for continuation of care?
clinician_response: SUMMARY 8 months old male with febrile convulsion   INVESTIGATIONS · CBC · Blood slide for malaria · CRP  · Renal function tests-deranged electrolytes can cause convulsion · Liver function tests-high bilirubin levels can cause convulsion   MANAGEMENT · Patient needs admission to ward · Start on antipyretics for the fever · Anticonvulsion for the convulsion · Analgesia for the pain · Consult paediatrian

scenario: I am a nurse working in a Health centres in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A 10-year-old girl was brought in by a relative in the OPD with the history of being defiled by a known person who is a 26-year-old man three hours ago. On examination, blood on her clothes, she was also in pain. Vaginal examination was done, absent of hymen, which was still fresh, blood stains and also evidence of semen around the vulva.  Was I to refer this girl to level 4 or was I to start to test if negative and start PEP or refer to the police?
clinician_response: A 10 year old girl brought by a relative presented with a history of defilement by a 26 year old man 3 hours ago. On examination, the patient was noted to have blood stains on her clothes. In pain, but a vaginal exam revealed absent hymen, blood stains and semen discharge.  Management:: Get further history around the incident. Complete blood count Urea,electrolyte and creatinine Liver function test Urinalysis  HIV Hepatitis * Administer oral antibiotics, analgesics, post-exposure prophylaxis and Hepatitis B vaccine booster. * Refer child to psychological counselor and initiate psychological first aid. * After all the above, refer to the police. * If patient has complications such as vaginal or anal tear, refer to Level 4 facility.

scenario: I am a nurse with 30 years of experience in General nursing working in a Health centres in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A 12-year-old girl is brought to the outpatient by her teacher with a history of nose bleeding that started two hours ago while in class. First aid has been done, but the nose bleeding is not stopping. The vital signs are within normal ranges.  I have requested for full hemogram, blood slide for malaria parasites, which is negative. How do I manage this client? Do I pack the nostrils with Vaseline or do I use adrenaline? Do I give injection vitamin K or refer her for ENT specialist to review?
clinician_response: A 12 year old girl with a history of nose bleeding that started two hours ago. Vitals signs are within normal range. Management of the patient:  * Pack the nose with gauze soaked in liquid paraffin to stop the bleeding.  * Adrenaline can also be used since it acts as a vasoconstrictor and can help reduce the bleeding.  * Administer tranexamic acid to help stop the bleeding.  * Assess the extent of blood loss by doing a Complete Blood Count and determine whether transfusion is needed. Investigations to be done:  * Complete Blood Count to assess Hb level  * Coagulation profile to rule out coagulopathies.  * Urea, Electrolytes and Creatinines because severe blood loss can lead to pre-renal AKI.  * For ENT review.

scenario: I am a nurse with 30 years of experience in General nursing working in a Health centres in Kakamega county in Kenya.  In maternity laboured, a client comes in. She is a para 5+1, gravida 6. She comes in having attended antenatal client just once, and she is in second stage of labour. She delivers triplets.  The babies had a weak cry at birth, and each of them weighs 1.5 and another one 1.7. The third stage of labour for the mother is normal. The placenta is complete with membranes and the blood loss is minimal, following active management of third stage of labour. What can I do to save these babies, and yet I don't have oxygen? One of the children, one of the neonates is turning blue.  Do I just wrap the baby to keep warm as I call for the ambulance, or do I keep on applying AMBU BAG, respiration until the ambulance comes? How do I save the three neonates?
clinician_response: Summary Para 5+1 gravida 6 delivers preterm and underweight babies with poor APGAR score. Babies are triplets. Facility has limited oxygen resources. Diagnosis:respiratory distress syndrome and birth asphyxia which is common in preterm deliveries   Management 1) Shout for help 2) Check airway for patency and suction any secretions visible 3) Assess the breathing of the babies and count respiration rate 4) Begin ambu bagging if the respiratory rate is low. Check the oxygen saturations and initiate oxygen therapy. Assess circulation and heart rate. Begin chest compressions at a rate of 15 breaths to two compressions 5) Establish IV cannulation and give IV dextrose 6) Plan for referral to a facility with provision for neonatal care unit 7) Keep babies warm

scenario: I am a nurse with 13 years of experience in General nursing working in a Health centres in Kakamega county in Kenya.   A one day old baby was brought in by the mother, who was 15 years old, and the grandmother. They came in with the history that the baby was... The baby is not breastfeeding well. And taking the history, they say that the delivery was a home delivery, which happened a day ago.  And also, the grandmother was telling me that there is some leakage on the back of the baby. So, when I did the examination, head to toe, everything was normal, except now that when I turned the back, I found that there is a leakage of cerebrospinal fluid, which I diagnosed to the baby to be having spina bifida. So, my question was, I asked myself, what's the immediate management that I can offer to this child? And if there is, if I am to refer, what are the protocols? How can I going to refer this child? And now that the family is unable even to have transport to take this child to the next level, can I get the ambulances around, can offer to take this baby to the higher level?
clinician_response: 1-day-old baby not breastfeeding well, delivered at home. Some leakage on back of baby. On examination, leakage of CSF. Diagnosis of spina bifida made. Child brought in by 15-year-old mother and grandmother. Head to toe examination otherwise normal.  Immediate Management:  1. Dress the wound to prevent further leakage – sterile gauze, ensure it is clean.   2. Neurological exam.   3. Lab tests – CSF analysis, full hemogram, renal function test.   4. Rehydrate patient with IV fluids.   5. Keep the child warm.   6. Call the referral hospital, speak with neurosurgical team. Organize for hospital transfer using the hospital ambulance.   7. Counsel the mother and grandmother on the nature of condition.

scenario: I am a nurse with 13 years of experience in General nursing working in a Health centres in Kakamega county in Kenya.  One day old child was brought into the facility by the mother who was 15 years old,and the grandmother. The baby was a home delivery and when we weighed the child, it was worth 1300 grams. The child had not suckled well since she was born.  This child has all signs of premature baby. How should I manage this baby, the immediate management of this newborn? If am supposed to refer, what are the protocols of referring this child? Now that the special place to be referred was NBU and we could not offer the service.
clinician_response: 1-day-old neonate taken to a health center, delivered at home. Birth weight: 1200 grams. Child unable to breastfeed. Features of prematurity. Dx: Prematurity. Very low birth weight  Immediate management: 1. Keep the baby warm using a radiant warmer or kangaroo mother care. 2. Assess the neonate for respiratory distress, administer supplemental oxygen if there is a need. 3. Administer prophylactic antibiotics.  Notes for referral: Ensure the mode of transport has the capability of providing warmth. If there is respiratory distress, administer oxygen. Secure a Nasogastric tube for feeding. Complete a referral form detailing clinical findings, history, and treatments provided. Provide clear communication (call the receiving facility). Counsel the family, mother, and grandmother.

scenario: I am a nurse with 13 years of experience in General nursing working in a Health centres in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A 13-year-old girl was brought in by the teacher, having a complaint of lower abdominal pain,PV discharge. I took the history, and the lady reports that the problem has there for a period of two months. And when I further probed, she reports to have been abused sexually by the mother's side guy, while the mother had gone to buy a credit in the evening, and the man took advantage of her and he abused her.  On palpation, there was lower abdominal pain. On a vaginal examination, they found that there was a discharge, creamy, which I sent to lab to do a urine analysis, HIV test and pregnancy test. I suspected a SGBV with PID. Is this is a SGBV case, what am I supposed to do after the results are out? Maybe they can be treated for the STI, where am I supposed to refer this SGBV case?
clinician_response: Summary  A 13 year old girl. A suspected victim of sexual based violence by someone known to her. Lower abdominal pain, per vaginal discharge for 2 months now.  Problems:  -Lower abdominal pain -Per vaginal bleeding -Psychologic tauma  Management:  -Start broad spectrum antibiotic, anti-fungal pessaries. -Take samples for pregnancy test, HIV, Syphilis from the patient. Consider taking HIV test from suspect. If suspect is not around, consider starting PEP (Post Exposure Prophylaxis). -Psychological counselling and involve relevant sexual gender based violence advocates at sexual gender based violence centre. -If Syphilis is present, start an antibiotic -If pregnant, consider talking to the patient on whether to keep the baby or do an individual abortion.

scenario: I am a nurse with 13 years of experience in General nursing working in a Health centres in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A 13-year-old girl was brought in by the mother with history of sweating, restlessness and lower abdominal pain. On history taking, the pain started at 4 am and at that time that they came to the facility it was around 12pm. I asked the girl about the last month menstrual period and she was not able to give me the information.  The mother also had no information about the same. On abdominal palpation, the fundal height was 35 for 40. The line was LOA, presentation was cephalic and I did a VE and the cervical dilatation she was fully dilated.  My question which came to my mind was, is it not a case of SGBV which was not identified and reported early? I did the delivery and the baby was premature. Although she scored well but now the circuit reflex was not there and this was a baby for referral for NBU management. How can we address the gaps, especially with the issues of pregnancy, with the SGBV cases which are not identified early and reported? How can we strengthen the community facility linkage for early referral?
clinician_response: 13-year-old female brought in by the mother with a history of abdominal pain for 8 hours, sweating, and restlessness. Last menstrual period: unknown. Clinical Findings: On abdominal examination: Fundal height was 35 for 40 weeks. Presentation: Longitudinal with cephalic presentation. Vaginal examination: Cervix fully dilated. Outcome: Delivery was completed. The baby, born prematurely, was referred to the neonatal care unit (NBU) for management. Baby scored well but exhibited a poor suckling reflex. Diagnosis: Pregnant minor. Interventions to Address Gaps: Early identification and reporting mechanisms. Psychological support. Development of protocols and policies for reporting such cases. Sexual health education. Community sensitization and education. Referral system improvement through proper protocols. Strengthening community facilities for early referral. Building partnerships between stakeholders. Developing clear referral pathways. Outreach services.

scenario: I am a nurse with 13 years of experience in General nursing working in a Health centres in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A baby was brought to the facility, maternity unit by a neighbor after being abandoned by the mother, who is a mentally ill woman. The mother didn't attend any ANC clinics, and she had been roaming about. The baby, on examination, the baby was small for dates, with signs of respiratory distress.  And I ordered for RBS, but the strips were out of stock. This is a ARDS case, respiratory distress syndrome, and this case resulted from asphyxia. What will be the immediate management of this baby, now that in the health center, there was no warmer. What is the referral protocol, so that this child can benefit after admission at the newborn unit? How can the community be sensitized on mental health, so that it can be addressed earlier, so that the mother can be well, and she can be able to take care of the baby after delivery?
clinician_response: Baby brought with by a neighbour with signs of respiratory distress and small for dates. The mother is mentally ill, didn't go to any antenatal clinic and has been roaming around. Random blood sugar strips were out of stock.  IMMEDIATE MANAGEMENT  Check for airway clearance and suction any secretions. Check for breathing (Chest wall expansion) and put the child on oxygen via non-rebreather mask. Check for circulation (Pulse, mucous membranes, skin turgor, sunken eyes). Cover the child with warm blankets since there is no warmer available to assist with dehydration. Place a large bore intravenous cannula and give warm fluids as dextrose and normal saline bolus and maintenance fluids. Refer the patient to the nearest facility with neonatal ICU / New born unit. Call an ambulance and hospital.    How can the community be sensitized on Mental health to avoid such scenarios?  Educate the community on signs and symptoms of mental disorders where they can get help and how not to stigmatize or isolate them. Educate on the importance of good social and family support.

scenario: I am a nurse working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A 11 year old girl was brought to the outpatient clinic, rushed in by the relatives, and she was walking with her legs apart, with some bleeding, with blood-stained clothes. The girl stays with her grandmother, upon asking questions, the girl revealed to have been sexually harassed or raped by the uncle, and the uncle threatened her not to reveal So, a diagnosis of rape was made, and so the question was, how will we manage the cause? Should we report to the relevant authority? Should we manage the child? Should we call the physio or psychotherapy to come and communicate with the girl? Thank you.
clinician_response: SUMMARY An 11 year old girl is rushed into an outpatient clinic by relatives, she came walking legs apart with some bleeding with blood stained clothes. History of sexual harrassment, raped by her uncle. The uncle threatened her not to reveal. A diagnosis of rape is made. How will you manage the case? Should you report to the authorities?  Manage the patient as follows: Stabilize the patient. Stop the bleeding Perform a pelvic examination; assess the vagina/cervix for any tears or injuries Resuscitate the patient if bleeding is in excess Reassure the patient Collect forensic samples; a vaginal swab for semen and DNA analysis, clothes Fill in a P3 form to involve the police Do the following labworks; HIV tests, STI screening and a Full hemogram Give post exposure prophylaxis for HIV Family planning Psychological counselling  Should we report to the authorities? Yes, as this is a minor and rape is a criminal offense Should we manage the child? Yes, as she is bleeding Should we call psychotherapy or physiotherapy to manage the child? Yes, for both emotional and psychological support.

scenario: I am a nurse working in a Health centres in Kakamega county in Kenya.  An eight-year-old girl is brought to the facility with her father, with a history of having been sexually assaulted by a 20-year-old Shamba boy. The girl seems to be frightened and she's in tears. On examination, it is clear that the girl has been assaulted from the physical examination.  We did HIV testing, which turned negative. So, according to this case scenario, which PEP regimen is this child eligible for? Which PEP regimen can she be initiated on? And what counselling should the child be given together with the father? And finally, which psychosocial support group can I refer this child and the father to?
clinician_response: Summary: 8 year old girl with history of sexual assault. Seems teary and frightened . On examination it is clear of the assault. HIV testing done turned negative.  Q1: Which PEP regimen can she be initiated?  Tenofovir plus emtricitabine if > 30kg <300 kg Abacavir and lamivudine   Q2: What counselling should she be given together with the father? Counsel on adherence of the post exposure prophylaxis for the 28 days Advice on the possible side effects of the PEP Advice on legal pathways if she chooses to persue the alleged perpetrator  Q3: Which psychosocial group can look after the father ?  Post rape survivors. Diagnosis: alleged defilement

scenario: I am a nurse working in a Sub-county Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A 10-year-old boy comes in with open wound. Gave a history that while he was playing with a cat the cat bit him. Temperature 36, no bleeding, it's a cat bite. What treatment do I give for a cat bite,if I dress should I close the wound or leave it open?
clinician_response: SUMMARY  A 10 year old boy comes in with open wound , reports that while playing with a cat , the cat bit him  Vitals Temperature- 36  What treatment do you give for a cat bite  Clean the wound - at least with soap with water  Asses for signs of infection if it has pus or foul smelling or redness give antibiotics Enquire on the Cat's vaccination if the cat has been vaccinated or it's status is unknown then give anti rabies at day 0 then day 3 , 7 , 14 and 28. If the cats vaccination status is UpTo date then no need for anti rabies   B  Should I close the wound  After cleaning the wound ensure to dry and dress but don't close the wound  Encourage the patient to always clean and dry.

scenario: I am a nurse with 2 years of experience in General nursing working in a Health centres in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A boy aged 10 yrs old has been injured by a motorcycle on the Left lower limb and sustained injuries. Has a big wound and might take a month for dressings and healing Temperature 36, there's a big wound. For how long should the client be on antibiotics, is it right to dress the wound with sugar,flagyl powder, or honey?
clinician_response: SUMMARY Boy 10yrs, Injury RTA, LLL, Head injury T 36.5  For how long should the client be on antibiotics? Is it right to dress the wound with sugar, fly powder, or honey?  In this scenario, antibiotics are not recommended as there is no wound, presence of cuts and bruises of loose connective tissue. Sugar is not recommended to dress the wound since it may introduce contamination to a clean wound.  For fly powder, if there is no indication for its use against positive contamination by anaerobes, then it has no role.

scenario: I am a nurse with 2 years of experience in General nursing working in a Health centres in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A 7/12 old boy was being given porridge and he started coughing. The caretaker reports that he was chocked by porridge. Baby Is restless and ha difficulty in breathing. What is the first aid management of choking, what should I do before I refer to higher level hospital?
clinician_response: Summary  7 month old baby boy presenting with chief complaints of restlessness, difficulty in breathing following administration of porridge that had him coughing immediately.   First aid management of choking Support the baby's head and neck Tilt the baby so that the head is lower than the torso Perform a few back slaps between the shoulder blades  Flip the infant over and perform a few chest thrusts  Repeat the procedures if the obk\ject/food is not out’ if it fails, rush to the nearest health facility after calling for help Before referral to a higher level facility Clear the patient's airway Insert endotracheal tube if unable to protect the airway Check SPO2 if less than 90% give oxygen via nasal prongs Monitor the child closely while waiting transfer to higher facility Monitor the child closely while waiting transfer to higher facility

scenario: I am a nurse with 2 years of experience in General nursing working in a Health centres in Kakamega county in Kenya.  A newborn is brought to facility with rashes all over the body.
